newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australian bonds succumb to mild correction.
newsitem.headline: Australian bonds succumb to mild correction.

text.p: *Australian bond yields rose as the market finally succumbed to a mild correction in the absence of any major local data and after the recent steamy advance.
*Focus returns to the U.S. which faces a barrage of data.
Australian bond yields rose as the market finally succumbed to a mild correction in the absence of any major local data and after the recent steamy advance.

Long-dated bond yields were creeping back over 7.0 percent after striking 3-1/4 year lows on Monday, while short-dated yields and bill futures gave up some their bullish tone as the Reserve Bank remained silent on monetary policy.

However, at 94.84, the September bills contract is still pricing in a cash rate of 5.16 percent compared with current 5.5 percent official interest rates, and the market will remain on RBA watch both before and after the July 1 board meeting.

The market ignored the 4.6 percent rise in first quarter housing starts, coming much in line with median expectations, and as the report was regarded as fairly old news given the housing sector is already known to be one of the few areas of the economy showing any signs of strength.

The U.S. Treasury market is expected to be the main driving force in the short-term, particularly in view of the barrage of data that is due out later on Tuesday, comprising CPI, housing starts, industrial production and capacity utilisation for May.
The U.S. market firmed on Monday, extending Friday's PPI-led rally.

The local corrective tone saw spread differentials widen against the dollar bloc after the recent strong outperformance. The yield curve also flattened after spiking sharply last week after a weak labour force report, which fuelled expectations of a further monetary policy easing.
